title: How to Test a Popcorn Ceiling for Asbestos

steps.headline: Research and follow all legal guidelines.
steps.description: Some states and areas require that you use a professional, certified by a government environmental organization, to collect and test any potential asbestos samples. Contact the local environmental regulatory agency for your area, such as the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at https://www.epa.gov/home/forms/contact-epa, to see if they allow self-gathering of samples and under what conditions. In the U.S. and possibly other countries, you'll need to find out state-specific laws in addition to national (EPA) laws.

steps.headline: Locate a lab and find out the sampling requirements.
steps.description: Home testing is usually not advised and may not be legal in all areas. Instead, go online to your environmental authority’s website and look for a certified asbestos-testing lab. Then, contact the lab to talk with them about their sampling requirements. Ask them if they’ll send you a kit or if you need to purchase one on your own and where to buy it. You can also get instructions regarding how they want the sample collected and sent to them. They may have specific requirements for the size of the sample, too. For example, an agency might allow you to sample and test material only from homes built in 1980 and onwards. Or, they might state that the ceiling must be completely intact and not under construction during the sampling process.

steps.headline: Purchase a sampling kit or buy the supplies separately.
steps.description: You can get an asbestos sampling kit for around $30-$60 from your local hardware store. This kit will contain everything you’ll need to safely remove the sample and contain it for shipping. You can also go to a home improvement store and shop for the items you’ll need on your own. For example, if you are buying the supplies on your own, then you’ll need to get multiple plastic baggies for containment and shipping. An asbestos kit will also contain a face mask, disposable coveralls, gloves, wipes, sample bags, shipping materials, and sample submission documents.

steps.headline: Hire a professional for sampling and removal, alternatively.
steps.description: There are EPA-certified contractors who can help you with the sampling and testing process. If your sample comes back as positive for asbestos, you’ll also want to hire one of these companies. Find one of these professionals by contacting the environmental authority in your area. These companies must apply for and receive a special license to show that they know how to handle and dispose of asbestos.

steps.headline: Remove all furniture and items from the room.
steps.description: Since even the smallest speck of asbestos can cause health problems, it’s a good idea to completely clear out the room that you’ll be taking a sample from. If you can’t remove all the furniture, then push it far away from the sampling area and cover it all with plastic drop cloths.

steps.headline: Close the windows and shut off any fans.
steps.description: If you remove a sample from a ceiling, then asbestos particles can become airborne if you have air circulating in the room. To keep this from happening, turn off your heating or cooling system. Shut any windows or doors and keep any fans turned off.

steps.headline: Put on your safety gear.
steps.description: Wear coveralls or outer clothing that you won’t mind throwing away after taking the sample. You can usually buy disposable coveralls for $5-10 at your local hardware store. Wear heavy disposable gloves as well. And, put on a breathing mask (a paper one is fine) and goggles, too. It’s bad to let asbestos touch your skin, so keep totally covered. Remember that you’ll need to toss everything that you’ve worn on the outside, including goggles and gloves. So, don’t spend a lot on them. While you are taking the sample and before you’ve fully cleaned up, don’t let anyone else in the room.

steps.headline: Lay plastic drop cloths on the floor.
steps.description: Get industrial plastic sheeting from your hardware store. Place this sheeting on the floor directly under where you’ll take the sample. Use duct tape to secure the sheeting to the floor, so that it won’t shift around. Set your ladder directly on top of the sheeting and under where you’ll take the sample.

steps.headline: Mist the room with water.
steps.description: When you’ve finished placing the plastic, get a spray bottle and mist the whole space with water. This helps to keep any dust particles from floating around. It’s not necessary to saturate any surfaces, just a quick spraying will do fine.

steps.headline: Loosen a sample with a utility knife.
steps.description: Holding your utility knife or chisel carefully, press it against the ceiling. Form an outline around the area that you wish to remove. Don’t fully remove the piece at this point, just loosen it up. However, if the piece begins to fall out, skip ahead to the step with the plastic baggies. You’ll want to consult with the EPA, your chosen testing company, or your sample kit to determine how big of a piece you’ll need. Some samples can be relatively small while other labs might need a larger piece.

steps.headline: Fold a damp paper towel into the plier’s mouth.
steps.description: Pick up your pliers from the floor. Open the mouth and fold a wet wipe or moist paper towel inside. This will lessen the likelihood that an asbestos fiber will stick to your tool. Keep the wipe in place as you raise the pliers toward the ceiling.

steps.headline: Pull the sample away from the ceiling with the pliers.
steps.description: Open the mouth of the pliers. Place the tips of the pliers against the ceiling, so that they fully grasp the edges of the potential sample. Push the plier tips deeper into the ceiling material and gently squeeze inwards. This will give you control over the sample. Slowly pull your pliers away from the ceiling, taking the sample with you. If the sample is stuck in the ceiling, you may need to rock it back and forth a bit, but do so very gently.

steps.headline: Drop the sample into a plastic bag.
steps.description: Get a plastic baggie that came with your kit, or just a sealable freezer baggie. Open it up and drop the sample directly inside. Loosen the wipe from the pliers and put it in the bag as well.

steps.headline: Seal and label the bag.
steps.description: Run your fingers across the top seal until it is fully secure. For extra security, you might place this original bag in another one and seal that as well. Use a permanent marker to write your name, your city, and the date on the bag. Some sampling kits will provide additional instructions regarding labeling the bag, such as using a particular stick-on label.

steps.headline: Perform another round of water misting.
steps.description: Set the sample to the side of the room. Then, get your water sprayer and mist down the entire area. The goal is to spray everything in the room, even the plastic sheeting on the floor. This helps any stray asbestos particles to stay down.

steps.headline: Paint the sampled area.
steps.description: Get any type of interior paint. Dip your brush into it and coat the spot where you took the sample. This will keep the opened sample area from releasing any potentially dangerous dust over time. Throw the brush and paint away after use. If you took a large sample, then you might want to add some drywall paste to the area before painting. Dip your drywall knife into the compound container. Then, apply the compound paste to the wall. Use your drywall knife to smooth over the area. This will make your sample spot less noticeable.

steps.headline: Dispose of the plastic sheeting.
steps.description: Roll up the plastic flooring from one end to the other. Then, place it into a large garbage bag. Seal the bag up with tape at the top to prevent any fibers from escaping into the air. You can also put on a fresh pair of gloves at this point. Place your old ones in the trash bag.

steps.headline: Vacuum the room.
steps.description: Pull out your vacuum and go over the entire floor. When you are finished, take out the vacuum bag and throw it away. If you have a bagless vacuum, wipe down the inside of the canister with a damp paper towel. Throw the used towels away.

steps.headline: Dispose of your clothing and gear.
steps.description: When you are finished with the entire project, place your outer clothing, gloves, and mask into a trash bag. Then, tape up the top and throw it all away.
